page.title: 10LYDFORD'S GROWTH
page.content: In Anglo Saxon times Lydford was a thriving settlement with strong defences and a Mint, but as the towns neighbouring it grew so Lydford's prosperity declined in spite of being the seat of the Stannary Parliament. The Castle fell into ruins and the village became very poor.It was not until 1870 that fortunes changed.Then the G.W.R. and the S.R. both built railway lines through the village from Exeter and N.Devon to Plymouth.This made a change for the better because visitors began coming to enjoy the Moors.Hotels were built to accomodate them. Today the railways have gone but tourists come in large numbers and are catered for with Bed and Breakfast, Hotels, camp sites and pony trekking. In addition the population has been increased by people settling in Lydford for their retirement years.
